WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 358 September 1979' Inter-Country Comparison of "Real" (PPP) Incomes: Revised Estimates and Unresolved Questions Adjusting for purchasing power parities of national currencies makes a significant difference to inter-country income comparisons. However, PPP estimates require detailed price data which are not readily available for most countries. Kravis, Heston and Summers have used regression analysis to extend their PPP estimates from the sixteen countries for which they have detailed prices to any country for which data are available on the share of trade in GDP and on inflation. The first part of this paper argues that a variant of this "short cut" approach, one which relies on measures of human resource development rather than on trade and inflation, is preferable on theoretical and statistical grounds. The second part of the paper raises a more fundamental issue. It argues that the treatment of services in their detailed analysis, and hence in any short-cut approach derived from it, is biased. This bias tends to exaggerate the PPP incomes of countries with relatively good human resource development, and so produces misleading esti- mates of relative incomes among poor countries and of the gap between poor and rich countries.  INTER-COUNTRY COMPARISON OF "'REAL" (PPP) INCOMES: REVISED ESTIMATES AND UNRESOLVED QUESTIONS* Introduction There is now fairly widespread awareness of the inadequacies of comparing per capita incomes without making adjustments for the purchasing power parities (PPPs) of national currencies. In general, use of officia. exchange rates tends to understate incomes in poor countries, even though they often have overvalued exchanige rates. This is because price levels tend to be lower in these countries. Kravis, Heston and Summers have been working for a number of years on a major project to collect and analyze detailed price data in countries at all income levels. The results of "Phase 2" of their work, reporting PPP incomes for sixteen countries, indicate, for example, that use of PPP rather than nominal prices causes incomes of poor countries to increase by 100% to 200% in relation to that of the US (ICP, 1978). A major difficulty in using PPP prices is the time, expense and political and administrative problems of gathering detailed price data for every country for which PPP income estimates are desired. Therefore, to develop a set of PPP incomes that can be used for cross-country analysis, Kravis, Heston, and Summers have used regression analysis to develop a "short- cut" method of predicting PPP incomes for over one hundred countries (KHS, 1978, thereafter referred to as KHS).- They derive a set of regression co- efficients which fairly faithfully (R2= .99) reproduce the PPP incomes of the sixteen countries for which detailed estimates for 1970 were available, They then use the coefficients to predict purchasing power parity incomes for any country for which aggregate trade and inflation (GDP deflator) data are available. No price data for individual goods and services are required for these short-cut estimates. The first par.- of this paper suggests an alternate approach to short-cut estimates, The second considers the need to address an apparent bias in the detailed ICP approach -- a bias which would affect conclusions reached on such key questions as the extent and distribution of world poverty, or the impact of income level on consumption patterns. I. Revised Estimates: KHS argue persuasively that the main reason for the difference between PPP and official exchange rate estimates of GDP is in services and other non-1.raded goods. The real (PPP) per capita GDP of the low-income country consequently will be higher relative to that of a comparison of their nominal GDPs per capita" (KHS, p. 220). This importance of non-. ½aded goods is apparent from the "full-information" PPP estimates reported in the ICP study. For their four lowest income countries, Kenya, India, Philippines and South Korea, non-traded goods were revalued upward by an unweighted average of 341%, while for traded goods the increase was only 78%. In the case of India, the inrrease for non-traded goods was 646% while that for traded goods was 102% yielding a weighted average for GDP of 234%. Using the ICP terminology, the "deviation index" -- the ratio of PPP to conventional incomes -- for India was 7.46 for non-traded goods, 2.02 for traded goods, and 3.34 for total GDP. KHS seek to explain inter-country differences in the deviation index for GDP in terms of variables affecting or measuring the extent of international trade, arguing that a country "more exposed to the world econ- omy is likely to have its non-traded goods prices pulled up closer to (those) of high-income countries" (p. 221). In their regression analysis KHS use three independent variables: conventional GDP; an index of "openness" -- imports plus exports as a percentage of conventional GDP; and "price isola- tion" -- the (square of the) difference in inflation from that of their esti- mated "world" average. Although there is a plausible case that the latter two variables have an impact on the deviation index, KHS themselves niote that there is room for question about the expected direction of that impact. In particular, one might well think that (with constant exchange rates) the greater a country's price isolation -- i.e., the higher its inflation* -- then the higher its internal prices in relation to international prices, and the lower its PPP income. The KHS hypothesis is, however, the opposite -- that "the greater the price isolation the less a country's non-traded goods price will be pulled up ... and the larger will be real income" (KHS, p. 223). KHS summarize the evolution of thinking on why the prices of non- traded goods, which are largely personal services, tend to vary with income level. Implicit in their summary is that there are constraints on the inter- national mobility of labor, including the financial and psychic costs of migration and restrictions on immigration into high wage countries. These constraints keep the prices of services from being bid up, through trade, to international levels. To the extent that there are constraints on interna- tional labor mobility, then the price of services should be determined by supply and demand within relevant segments of the domestic labor markets. This approach appears to have a less unambiguous basis in theory than that put forward by KHS. * While the mean squared deviation from "world" average inflation could reflect inflation either above or below thaL average, in practice the high "price isolation" values (p. 216) were all associated with above- average inflation.
 -3- The specific hypothesis pursued here is that the supply of labor of various skill categories (relative to average incomes) is a key determinant of the deviation index for non-traded goods, and hence that for GDP as a whole. Conventional per capita income, which is already included as an independent variable in the KHS i:egression analysis, would serve as a proxy for inter- country differences :in the wage for unskilled and semi-skilled services (as well as for differences in the price of traded goods). However, it cannot serve as a satisfactory proxy for the wage for skilled services, in view of the substantial differences in the labor supply for skilled services (e.g., the supply of teachers) among low-income countries, due to cultural, his- torical and political factors. The difference between India and Kenya in this regard, for example, is well known. India has a much greater supply, in relation to demand, of highly trained manpower, and because of its well- developed educational system can increase 4his supply relatively cheaply. In the following regression analysis, two approaches are used. One is a pure "short-cut" method, which relies only on published international data series and does not require price data per se. The other is a combina- tion short-cut and limited-information approach, which like the short-cut method makes use of regression analysis, but which also includes selected observed price data. The short-cut approach has the advantage of quickly yielding estimates fdr any country for which even minimal data are available, and is potentially useful as a substitute for conventional income data in cross-country analysis. However, it is too crude a tool to be aicepted as a firm basis for setting an income level for any given country. Limited infor- mation approaches, which require gathering consistent price data on, for example, forty commodities, are likely eventually to provide superior and more generally acceptable results to those of short-cut analysis. However, collecting a consistent series of prices for well over one hundred countries is a formidable task, even for only forty commodities. Thus, it may be that the hybrid short-cut limited-information approach, which would require a very small number of prices for each country covered, may be the best available approach for the next several years. The independent variables tried, in the short-cut analysis, were rates of literacy, secondary enrollment, and university enrollment. Coeffi- cients of any of the three would be expected to be positive, since the supply of trained manpower for which they are a proxy would be negatively related to the price of services and hence positively related to PPP incomes and devia- tion indexes. The choice among these variables would depend on the relative importance of the differing skill levels they represent in explaining inter- country differences in the price of services. (Because of colinearity, only one among them would be expected to be significant in any given equation.) The price variables tried were the wages, at official exchange rates, for teachers, skilled workers and white collar workers. Here expected signs would be nega- tive; higher wages for services would be related to lower PPP incomes and deviation indexes.
 - 4 - Conventional per-capita income was included as a variable in both the short-cut and combination equations. Following both KHS and the labor- supply hypothesis advanced here, its sign would be negative, and the devia- tion index would decrease as conventional incomes increase. Various specifi- cations of the variables were tried, including that of KHS (double-log with quadratic treatment of income). "Stepwise" analysis was used to choose the best statistical fit among alternate plausible explanatory variables. Since the human-resource approach used here is not necessarily inconsistent with the KHS trade-related approach, separate regression runs were carried out which also included "openness" and "price isolation." The specification of the dependent variable differed from that of KHS. Their dependent variable was the ICP estimate of PPP per capita GDP, expressed as a percent of US per capita GDP. A difficulty with this speci- fication is that since both series grcei roughly in parallel, conventional income alone explains 98.6Z of the variance (in their log quadratic specifi- cation). This does not leave much room to distinguish among other explana- tory variables. The best result obtained by KHS explained 98.9% of the vari- ance, or only .3% more than with income alone. To distinguish among other plausible variables is particularly important for those interested in com- parative incomes or poverty incidence in low-income countries. To deal with this problem, the deviation index was used as the independent variable. In- come explains a still high but slightly smaller percent of the variance (92% in a log quadratic specification). The deviation index also gives more stat- istical weight to the low-income countries, since its variance is much greater at lower incomes. Unresolved Questions: The previous section developed an alternate set of short-cut PPP income estimates for 129 countries, which it argued were more reliable than those of KHS as proxies for the information ICP estimates. This section raises some questions, though, about the full information estimates themselves. We have seen that the KHS deviation index is highly dependent on the relative price of services. In the ICP approach to international comparisons, PPP prices for services are those wvhich one would have to pay in the (expenditure weighted) "world" average country - i.e., in a relatively high-income country. But how is that international price determined? KHS state "internal factor mobility will lead to high wages also in non-traded goods in higher produc- tivity countries" (KHS, p. 219). In other words the "international" price of services (or other non-tradables) is measured essentially by the oppor- tunity cost of the labor and other resources used to produce them in a rela- tively high-productivity (income) country. How useful is it to measure the price of services in this manner? Let us consider the implications for resource allocation, taking the example of primary and secondary education. Numerous studies have shown positive (social and private) returns to education in India. But if we value education in India at "international" prices, we would revalue it upward by about fifteen times. In contrast, the value of the agricultural and indus- trial traded goods produced by those educated would at international prices only be doubled. With costs revalued upward by fifteen times, and benefits doubled, returns would turn negative and so there would be little economic justification for expenditures on education in India.** Similarly, if fac- tories, and their leasing costs, are revalued upward by 900% but their output * The correlation between the Clague and Tanzi education variable and conventional per capita income was .66 for the relevant sample of thirteen OECD countries; the correlation between conventional per capita income and the deviation index was .91. ** To argue against this point on grounds that education should be valued purely as a consumption good, rather than as a human capital investment, would not be credible, particularly for low-income countries.
 -9 is revalued by only 100% (i.e., the average for traded goods), there would be little justification for building factories. This problem is a serious one, since many or most services (or other non-traded goods) are, in essence, intermediate (or investment) goods rather than consumption goods per se. The obverse side of this problem is that output maximization at ICP prices would call, for example, for huge increases in middle and higher education, in spite of educated unemployment, and in factory construction, more or less irrespective of demand. More generally, output maximization would be achieved by shifting toward those expenditures which would be revalued by high multiples (i.e., those with a high deviation index).* For example, from 1970-76, Sri Lanka attempted to address some of its unemploy- ment problem by increasing public sector employment more rapidly than the (low) growth in output in either agriculture or industry. At ICP prices, though, this growth in services would be revalued upward by a large multiple, and thus GDP growth at ICP prices would seem misleadingly high. In sum, ICP prices do not appear useful either for resource allocation, or for measuring or comparing income growth rates. In much the same manner, ICP prices have weaknesses as a guide to measuring consumption per se. For example, how meaningful is it to say that, if an Indian farmer hires an agricultural laborer, the farmer's ICP income would go up by less than a tenth of the increase that would have occurred if he had hired the same individual to work as a housThold servant?** The ICP approach does have an understandable appeal, tbough. There is some- thing rather democratic in saying, for example, that an hour of a nurse's time is worth the same amount no matter what the cost of her training or the incomes of those she treats. However, as noted previously, the "inter- national" price of the nurses' services is determined by the opportunity cost of these services (in terms of traded goods) in a relatively high-pro- ductivity country. It is not at all a "pure" consumption price. * This would be true to some extent in the long run as well as the short run. The opportunity cost, such as decreased food output, that would be incurred from 'excessive' expenditures on services with a high deviation index would be sharply reduced by present-value discounting. ** The point here is not that the same set of prices need necessarily be used for all purposes. In this case, however, the examples illustrate not only the problems of using ICP prices for intra-country resource allocation or consumption comparisons, but the reason why inter-country comparisons based on the assumption of equal marginal productivity of services are misleading.
 - 10 - The above problems arise because the ICP treatment of services is saying, in effect, that if there were perfect international mobility of labor and if, therefore, the marginal productivity of services were the same in India as in a relatively high-income country, then services in India would be grossly underpriced in relation to traded goods.* But the assumptions are incorrect and so, therefore, is the implication that the international price is the "real" price for services in poor countries. Put another way, to assume equal prices for (identical) services is to assume equal availability (and "X" efficiency) of the complementary factors of production that determine the marginal productivity of those ser- vices. In a private communication Kravis indicates that ideally the ICP comparisons for, e.g., doctors should take account of the effect on their productivity of complementary capital inputs, such as expensive medical equip- ment. However, if this is true, then the same should apply to the whole range of services (e.g., barbers, extension agents or engineers) and to other non- traded goods (e.g., building rents). What options are there that are consistent with the ICP general approach, but which can deal with the problems of pricing non-traded goods? First, weighting could be by population rather than by income. As indicated in the discussion above, the ICP "international" price is, in essence, the price faced by a person with the (relatively high) average per capita income of the non-S' ialist countries. The person with the per capita income (or, more precisely, expenditure) of $2,000 gets, on the average, 20 price "votes" for every one of a person at $100 per capita. Kuznets (1972) has shown how this principle produces estimates of country per capita income growth that greatly overstates the growth enjoyed by the majority of the population. To correct this, he proposed weighting per capita income growth by population rather than income; average income growth would be measured by the average of individual income grow.h rates, with the growth rate of the poor weighted as much as the growth rate of the rich. Chenery and Ahluwalia have applied this same principle to intra-country income weighting (Chenery et al., 1974). Why not apply it also to determining international prices for PPP comparisons?** * The same general argument also applies in the case of other non-traded goods, primarily construction; here the implicit KKHS assumption is that productivity of investment in buildings and other non-traded goods is as high in India as in a relatively high-income country. ** A simplified expenditure-weighted index would be (Q P )/ ;Q., where Q is quantity, P price and i the country subscript. The comparaile popu- lation-weighted index would be (Pop.P.) ,Pop.. For example, let us take two countries. The first has a population of one million and con- sumes ten million haircuts at an average cost of $5. The second has a population of ten million and consumes one million haircuts at an average cost of $1. Conventional expenditure weights would put the average price of $4.64, while with population weights the average price would be only $1.36.
 Second, non-traded goods could be set at a price to retain their ratio to the average price of traded goods (which would be revalued in PPP terms).* This would follow from the point noted earlier about the effect of the %ack of international mobility of labor on actual marginal produc- tivity (vs. the ICP use of hypothetical international marginal productivity). Either of these two approaches would be relatively easy to compute, using the detailed ICP data. As with other aspects of the index number problem (e.g., the choice between Paasche and laspeyeres indices), there is no reason that one single method of valuing services needs to be adopted to the exclusion of all others. For example, in comparing incomes among low-income countries it might well be argued that prices in middle and upper income countries are irrelevant and should not be used if - as is likely - they would mate- rially change relative incomes among the low-income countries. In practice, it would not be feasible to have more than one published PPP income level (or at most two) for each country. Nevertheless, the marginal cost of car- rying out special PPP income comparisons among particular groups of countries is quite modest, given the availability of relevant country data and computer programs. When "Phase 3" of the ICP is completed, there will be "full-infor- mation" estimates available for about fifteen developing countries; the exact number would depend on one's definition of a developing country. This would be enough to allow use of regression analysis to develop short-cut estimates for other developing countries. Needless to say, the short-cut and limited information regression approaclhes discussed above would have to be substantially revised if the treatument of services is revised. III. Conclusions This paper has suggested the importance of human resource supply in determining PPP incomes and has demonstrated its impact on short-cut and combination short-cut limited-information estimates. Hopefully, the evolution of research in this area will carry PPP income estimates well beyond what is proposed here. It may be, for example, that there are some variables which will serve as proxies for human-resources supply but add additional informa- tion; or, as suggested above, the human-resource and KHS approaches may be reconcilable. The availability of "full information" price data for thirty- four countries under the ongoing third phase of the ICP project will help to broaden the basis for short-cut, limited information and comtination approaches. * Prof. Kravis has pointed out that reducing international income compari- sons on the basis of only a few prices would defeat much of the purpose of the comparisons. However, the ICP category of traded goods is quite broad, so this problem (rather than the disputed problem of how to treat services) should not arise.
 - 12 - However, we have also seen that the ICP treatment of non-traded goods, which is the key determinant of variance in the deviation index at any given income level, has major limitations. This is not to say that the ICP treatment is "wrong." It follows the accepted practice for international price comparisons* (which grew from initial attempts to compare incomes among relatively similar European economies). The problem, rather, derives from the well-known theoretical problem of making cardinal comparisons of inter- personal utility. There is no unique "correct" set of weights (prices). Those that best answer questions relating to how much an international traveler would have to pay for a given basket of goods and services may not be those that best answer questions relating to inter-country comparisons. Specifically, the ICP approach appears to overstate the PPP incomes both of poor countries in relation to those of rich countries and, among poor coun- tries, of those whose services have been revalued upward the most. In other words, it understates the relative poverty of low-income countries, particu- larly of those in South Asia. Also, it would overstate the growth rates of countries with rapid growth in public sector employment or other services. These problems suggest caution in use of the KHS estimates for international income comparisons, at least for low income countries, until they can be resolved. There are also a few problems with the ICP data. It is even more difficult, for example, to control for the quality of services (and thus to compare like "quantities" of a given service among countries) than in the case of commodities. For instance, the ICP data shows that dental services in Kenya cost 100 times those in India; this raises the question of whether the Kenyan data may not be more middle-class oriented than the Indian data. In spite of these problems, though, the landmark work of the ICP project provides an important tool to improve our understanding of relative prices and incomes. With some change in the treatment of services, their PPP estimates would become more directly useful as a partial substitute for conventional income estimates. The other data problems do not appear major and can probably be handled effectively as more experience is gained in implementing the ICP approach. Also, in spite of the arguments above, the KHS PPP estimates may be a relatively utseful index of welfare, or of meeting "basic needs," in poor countries. In particular, the supply of trained people tends to be related not just to PPP incomes, but to the cost and coverage of education and health programs and to education and health status. Thus, the second- ary enrollmer-t ratio used in the regression analysis presented here is closely correlated with literacy, which is a determinant, along with per capita income, of infant mortality and life expectancy. doc.repnme: Inter-country comparison of "Real" (PPP) incomes : revised estimates and unresolved questions
doc.abstracts: Adjusting for purchasing power parities of national currencies makes a significant difference to inter-country income comparisons. However, PPP estimates require detailed price data which are not readily available for most countries. Kravis, Heston and Summers have used regression analysis to extend their PPP estimates from the sixteen countries for which they have detailed prices to any country for which data are available on the share of trade in GDP and on inflation. The first part of this paper argues that a variant of this short-cut approach, one which relies on measures of human resource development rather than on trade and inflation, is preferable on theoretical and statistical grounds. The second part of the paper raises a more fundamental issue. It argues that the treatment of services in their detailed analysis, and hence in any short-cut approach derived from it, is biased. This bias tends to exaggerate the PPP incomes of countries with relatively good human resource development, and so produces misleading estimates of relative incomes among poor countries and of the gap between poor and rich countries.
